newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine sanctions may end soon - US Commerce Sect..
newsitem.headline: Argentine sanctions may end soon - US Commerce Sect..

text.p: U.S. Commerce Secretary William Daley said Friday Washington may soon lift trade sanctions on some Argentine products on which countervailing duties have been clamped.
"A preliminary review by .... the Department of Commerce has recommended the rescission of those," Daley told a news conference on the second day of a three-day visit. "That will be final shortly."
Argentina has been saying for weeks that the United States would soon revoke countervailing duties on imports of Argentine wool, hides, seamles steel tubes and rolled steel.
Thursday evening Argentine Economy Minister Roque Fernandez said Daley told him the sanctions may be lifted soon but gave no precise dates.
Daley also said he expected a U.S. announcement soon on the possible approval of a 20,000-tonne annual import quota of Argentine beef.

Argentine beef has been denied access for decades to major markets because of its problems with foot-and-mouth disease, but international health authorities are due to declare the country free of the desease within the next few weeks.
Daley said President Bill Clinton had told his Agriculture Secretary last year to give a review of policy on Argentine beef imports "a very very high priority"
"I am hopeful that in the very near future there will be an announcement," he said.
Daley met Thursday Foreign Minister Guido Di Tella and President Carlos Menem. He flies back home on Saturday.
